recipes.cookingMethod:
1. In a large pot, brown the lamb on all sides in the clarified butter. 
2. Add water and baharat spice mix. Cover and simmer until the lamb is tender, about 2 hours. 
3. In a separate pot, cook the rice in 2 cups of water until tender. 
4. In a saucepan, heat the yogurt on low heat, stirring constantly. Do not allow it to boil. 
5. In a skillet, toast the pine nuts until golden brown. 
6. To serve, arrange the rice on a large platter. Top with the lamb and pour the yogurt over the meat. 
7. Sprinkle with toasted pine nuts and serve hot.

1. Rinse the bulgur wheat and drain well. In a large bowl, mix the bulgur with 2 cups of water and let it sit for 30 minutes to soften. 
2. In a skillet, sauté the onion until golden brown. Add the ground lamb and cook until browned. Season with baharat spice mix, salt, and pepper. 
3. Drain any excess water from the bulgur and add it to the lamb mixture. Mix well until the bulgur is fully incorporated. 
4. Form the mixture into small balls or torpedo shapes. 
5. Heat the vegetable oil in a deep skillet or pot over medium-high heat. 
6. Carefully add the kibbeh to the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crispy. 
7. Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels. 
8. Serve hot with tahini sauce and a sprinkle of toasted pine nuts.

ingredients: 1/4 cup olive oil, plus more for drizzling
recipes.cookingMethod:
1. In a food processor, blend the chickpeas until smooth. 
2. Add tahini, garlic, olive oil, lemon juice, cumin, salt, and black pepper. Mix well. 
3. If the hummus is too thick, add water or more olive oil, 1 tablespoon at a time, until desired consistency is achieved. 
4. Adjust seasoning to taste. 
5. Transfer to a bowl and drizzle with olive oil. 
6. Serve with pita bread or vegetables.

shortBio: Ahmad Al-Saad is a renowned chef from Amman, Jordan. He specializes in traditional Jordanian and Arabian cuisine, and has over 20 years of experience in the culinary arts. His signature dish is Mansaf, which is a must-try for anyone visiting Jordan.

recipes.cookingMethod:
1. In a large pot, heat the oil over medium heat. 
2. Add the whole spices and cook until fragrant, about 2-3 minutes. 
3. Add the lamb and cook until browned on all sides. 
4. Add water and salt. Cover and simmer until the lamb is tender, about 2 hours. 
5. In a separate pot, cook the rice according to package instructions. 
6. Serve the lamb and rice together with the cooking liquid poured over the top.

1. In a large pot, heat the oil over medium heat. 
2. Add the onion and garlic and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. 
3. Add the chicken and spices and cook until browned on all sides. 
4. Add water and salt. Cover and simmer until the chicken is cooked through, about 30-40 minutes. 
5. In a separate pot, cook the rice according to package instructions. 
6. Serve the chicken and rice together with the cooking liquid poured over the top.

1. Rinse the bulgur wheat and drain well. In a large bowl, mix the bulgur with 2 cups of water and let it sit for 30 minutes to soften. 
2. In a skillet, sauté the onion until golden brown. Add the ground lamb and cook until browned. Season with baharat spice mix, salt, and pepper. 
3. Drain any excess water from the bulgur and add it to the lamb mixture. Mix well until the bulgur is fully incorporated. 
4. Form the mixture into small balls or torpedo shapes. 
5. Heat the vegetable oil in a deep skillet or pot over medium-high heat. 
6. Carefully add the kibbeh to the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crispy. 
7. Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels. 
8. Serve hot with tahini sauce and a sprinkle of toasted pine nuts.

shortBio: Fatima Ahmed is a chef from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. She specializes in traditional Arabian cuisine, and has over 15 years of experience in the culinary arts. Her signature dish is Mandi, which is a slow-cooked lamb and rice dish that is popular in the Arabian Peninsula.

ingredients: 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley or cilantro
recipes.cookingMethod:
1. In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the onion and red bell pepper until softened, about 5-7 minutes. 
2. Add the garlic, paprika, cumin, salt, and black pepper. Cook for another minute. 
3. Add the crushed tomatoes and bring to a simmer. Cook until the sauce thickens slightly, about 10-15 minutes. 
4. Make 4-6 wells in the sauce and crack an egg into each well. 
5. Cover the skillet and cook until the egg whites are set but the yolks are still runny, about 5-7 minutes. 
6. Garnish with chopped fresh parsley or cilantro and serve hot with crusty bread or pita.

1. Preheat oven to 350°F. 
2. In a large bowl, separate the kunafa dough into small pieces with your fingers. Pour the melted butter over the dough and mix well. 
3. In a separate bowl, mix together the ricotta cheese and shredded mozzarella cheese. 
4. Press half of the kunafa dough mixture into a 9x13 inch baking dish. 
5. Spread the cheese mixture over the kunafa dough. 
6. Cover the cheese mixture with the remaining kunafa dough. 
7. Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 30-35 minutes. 
8. While the kunafa is baking, make the sugar syrup by combining the sugar, water, and orange blossom water in a small saucepan. Bring to a boil and cook until the sugar dissolves and the syrup thickens slightly. 
9. When the kunafa is done, remove from the oven and pour the sugar syrup over the top. 
10. Garnish with chopped pistachios and serve warm.

1. In a food processor, blend the chickpeas until smooth. 
2. Add tahini, garlic, olive oil, lemon juice, cumin, salt, and black pepper. Mix well.

6. Serve with pita bread or vegetables.

shortBio: Fatima Al-Saleh is a skilled chef from Dubai, UAE. She has over 15 years of experience in cooking Arabian cuisine and is well-known for her delicious Shakshuka and Kunafa. Her passion for cooking has led her to explore and experiment with new flavors and ingredients.
